title: Jamie Oliver – Comfort Food – Layered 3D Type
content:
Hi all,

This is driving me a bit nuts. There's a great 3D/layered font in the new Jamie Oliver book 'Comfort Food' that isn't listed at the front of the book. Its looks pretty damn similar to Industry Inc but I can see the M is slightly different. The inline stroke in the book touches the bottom of the letter, in Industry Inc it stops short. Amongst other things, its a different font of course.

Any ideas?

thanks,

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [DSC\_0632\_.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20140927000401/http:/typophile.com/files/DSC_0632_.jpg) | 179.08 KB |
| [DSC\_0633\_.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20140927000401/http:/typophile.com/files/DSC_0633_.jpg) | 133.43 KB |
| [DSC\_0635\_.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20140927000401/http:/typophile.com/files/DSC_0635_.jpg) | 174.25 KB |
author: fourcolourblack

comments.content:
For a minute, I thought it might be Politica by Sudtipos, but the S is off (good sloped-sided M, though).

Still looking.....
Can't be 100% positive but could be UT [Player](http://web.archive.org/web/20140927000401/http:/uppertype.net/fonts/player.htm), inline type treatment included.

Good call, Ryuk.

The GORGEOUS above GADO GADO appears to be Trend Slab, for what it's worth:  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/latinotype/trend/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140927000401/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/latinotype/trend/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/latinotype/trend/")

Sorry I should have mentioned that, I knew (and own) Trend.

UT Player is close, but its still not exactly the same.

Its not Prismatic either

[https://www.myfonts.com/fonts/matchandkerosene/prismatic/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140927000401/https:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/matchandkerosene/prismatic/ "https://www.myfonts.com/fonts/matchandkerosene/prismatic/")
Which aspects of UT Player are giving you pause, 4CB, if I may ask?

I don't know how you could state so easily it's not Player because I don't see any earmark that could contradict it: /M with sloppy verticals, /S straight oblique transition, low counter /R, /M inline vertex lower position, /K diagonals connecting to vertical via horizontal bar...

Video about the book design (specific typefaces not mentioned):  
 [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OPLwnvkgR\_g](http://web.archive.org/web/20140927000401/http:/www.youtube.com/watch?v=OPLwnvkgR_g "http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OPLwnvkgR\_g")

I'm guessing that "my friend James" is James Verity of Superfantastic:  
 [http://wearesuperfantastic.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140927000401/http:/wearesuperfantastic.com/ "http://wearesuperfantastic.com/")

Ah sorry guys, you are right. Most certainly is Player. Based on how much the Player 3D stripes is used through this book, it'd have to be part of a typeface to make life easier. That, or set all the headline and constantly outline and paste in diagonal lines.

Much obliged guys!

We type geeks can get a bit overzealous--didn't mean to gang up on you, just curious about the typeface.

I've several of Jamie's other cookbooks, so thanks for bringing this one--and Superfantastic--to my attention. And thanks, Ryuk, for introducing me to yet another interesting type foundry.
